The energy transferred by an external force is not the work done by the force. If you push on an object such as ,for example, a wall or a chair, then there is an external force on the object. But, what are you actually doing or what is happening? You are transferring energy to the object in a specific direction. A push on an object is a transfer of energy to the object which means that an external force on an object is a transfer of energy to the object. The amount of energy transferred to an object by an external force would simply reflect the magnitude of the external force. A greater amount of energy transferred to an object would reflect a greater push or external force on the object. The energy transferred to an object by an external force is not the work done on the object.  Work is not really force times displacement(W ≠ F ⋅ d) because work is not a function of displacement. We can take a look at this inconsistency here. Let's take the equation Wnet = Fnet ⋅ d and compare it to Fnet = ma. We find "net force" and acceleration on opposite sides of the equation, but we find net force and displacement on the same side of the other equation. We know that a net force causes an acceleration and we also know that net work can only be done by a net force if it causes a displacement. So, why aren't net force and displacement on opposite sides of the equation since a net force causes a displacement in the same way that net force and acceleration are on opposite sides of the equation and a net force causes an acceleration?  The net work done on an object is not equal to the change in kinetic energy of the object because the work-energy principle is incorrect since the work done is not equivalent to the energy transferred. A push or an external force on an object is a transfer of energy to the object and the amount of energy transferred to an object by an external force would simply reflect the magnitude of the external force as explained. A net push or a net external force on an object ,similarly, is a net transfer of energy to the object and the amount of net energy transferred to an object by an net external force would simply reflect the magnitude of the net external force.   There is a net external force on the box to the right and there is a net external force on the ball to the left when the ball collides with the box in your example 5:34. This means that there is a net transfer of energy to the box toward the right and there is a net transfer of energy to the ball toward the left. The amount of energy transferred to the box would simply reflect the magnitude of the net external force on the box by the ball and ,likewise, the amount of energy transferred to the ball would simply reflect the magnitude of the net external force on the ball by the box. The net energy transferred to an object by a net external force is not the net work done on the object.  The net energy transferred to an object by a net external force causes a change in the kinetic energy of the object. The amount of change in kinetic energy of an object would simply reflect the magnitude of the net external force. A greater change in kinetic energy of an object by a net external force would reflect a greater net push or net external force on the object.  The change in kinetic energy of the box is due to the net transfer of energy and the amount of change in its kinetic energy reflects the magnitude of the net external force on the box not the work done on the box. The change in kinetic energy of the ball ,likewise, is due to the net transfer of energy and the amount of change in its kinetic energy reflects the magnitude of the net external force on the ball and not the work done on the ball. The change in kinetic energy of an object by a net external force is not equal to the net work done on the object.

The concept of work in Physics as what happens when a force causes a displacement of an object is completely erroneous or wrong and work ,hence, is not really force times displacement(F•d). Work is a vector quantity(i.e. it's not a scalar) and ,in general, is defined as a "physical-displacement(ms)" by or due to a force, an impulse, or a kinetic force.  The work-energy theorem stating that the net work done on an object equals the change in the kinetic energy of the object is completely erroneous or wrong too. It would be the net force on an object that is equal to the change in the kinetic energy of the object.

I've already pointed out everything wrong in this video with the timestamps. But, let's start with his claim at 6:40 that the net work done on an object is equal to the change in the kinetic energy of the object which refers to the work-energy theorem. This is represented by the equation Wnet = ΔKE or ,alternative, by Wnet = fnet * d. We can take these two equations and combine them into the equation ΔKE = fnet * d. The change in kinetic energy of an object moving at a constant acceleration is proportional to and depends on the displacement of the object acted on by a constant net force.  However, there is no corresponding equation for work as it relates to energy and there should be based on this. This really means that we need to consider work as it relates to energy first before we consider net work as it relates to energy. Work is done on an object when it is acted on by an external force and there is a displacement of the object that is caused by the external force which is represented by the equation W = f * d that has external force as a constant. The work done on an object is proportional to and depends on the displacement of the object acted on by a constant force. But, the work equation breaks down to the equation W = f * vt which would have both force and velocity as being constant. The work done on an object moving at a constant velocity is proportional to and depends on the time the object is acted on by a constant force.   Obviously, the work equation wouldn't reflect the change in kinetic energy of an object since an object moving at constant velocity doesn't have a change in its kinetic energy. But, an object cannot have a change in kinetic energy anyway if there is no energy transferred to it. Energy is transferred to an object that is acted on by an external force. We may relate this to the work equation in that the amount of work done on an object is indicative of the amount of energy transferred to the object acted on by a constant force.   W = f * d Energy transferred = f * d  Now, this seems all nice and good and everything seems to make sense until you consider that no work is even done on an object moving at a constant velocity by an external force. An external force is not required to keep an object in motion and ,so, an object in motion moving at a constant velocity does not require an external force to continue moving at a constant velocity. This also means that the displacement of an object moving at a constant velocity is not caused by an external force that is acting on it and ,hence, no work is done on the object by the external force.  The exception to this general statement is here on Earth with the presence of friction and gravity. Friction and gravity need to be balanced in order for an object to continue moving at a constant velocity. The energy transferred to an object in either scenario only balances out these external "forces" allows it to keep moving at a constant velocity and does not cause a displacement of the object.   It is important for you or anyone to understand everything here before I continue on. However, there is no point in continuing if you or anyone cannot first let go of the erroneous thinking that an external force acting on an object that is moving at a constant velocity causes a displacement of an object. This is a very important point because it establishes the fact that work is not done on an object moving at a constant velocity by an external force and that the energy transferred to the object by the external force cannot be used to determine work that is not done by the external force. This also means that the change in kinetic energy of an object acted on by a "net force"  cannot be used to determine the net work that is done by a net force.

But, an object cannot have a change in kine.tic energ.y anyway if there is no energ.y transferred to it. energ.y is transferred to an object that is acted on by an external forc.e. We may relate this to the wor.k equation in that the amount of wor.k done on an object is indicative of the amount of energ.y transferred to the object acted on by a constant forc.e.   W = f * d  energ.y transferred = f * d   Now, this seems all nice and good and everything seems to make sense until you consider that no wor.k is even done on an object moving at a constant velocity by an external forc.e. An external forc.e is not required to keep an object in motion and ,so, an object in motion moving at a constant velocity does not require an external forc.e to continue moving at a constant velocity. This also means that the displacement of an object moving at a constant velocity is not caused by an external forc.e that is acting on it and ,hence, no wor.k is done on the object by the external forc.e.  The exception to this general statement is here on Earth with the presence of friction and gravity. Friction and gravity need to be balanced in order for an object to continue moving at a constant velocity. The energ.y transferred to an object in either scenario only balances out these external "forc.es" allowing it to keep moving at a constant velocity and does not cause a displacement of the object.  It is important for you or anyone to understand everything here before I continue on.
